channel.title: External graphics card for laptops
channel.description:
I don't have the money for a new laptop right now, but a new cheap graphics card should be easily affordable and be much better than my current Radeon HD 4650
Im not a big hardware guy, but is it possible to use an external graphics card with a laptop, seeing as how its very hard and expensive to replace the internal one? Can they run side by side or would I have to switch dependency to the external one? And how risky is this?
Here are my laptop specs: [img]http://img829.imageshack.us/img829/9769/specse.png[/img]

item.title: External graphics card for laptops
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell

I want to sell my xbox for a gtx 480 but I cant use it

Read full topic

item.title: External graphics card for laptops
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Updated my drivers shortly after that picture, and defragged.

The whole reason Im asking this was because I can run crysis on high, but I cant run rift on low. I realized it was rift thats unoptimized as there are tons of complaints.

Read full topic

item.title: External graphics card for laptops
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You basically aren’t going to find an external graphics card you can use, I’ve seen USB ones, but you would have to use them with an external monitor and the bus speed is so slow it couldn’t possibly be better than what you have already. Update your drivers, you can give some more RAM to the video card, then just save up for a new computer.

Read full topic

item.title: External graphics card for laptops
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:3, topic:403241”]Turns out the external cards are over $600 and use a proprietary port

But I also found:

“What you can do is check in the bios, by hitting F10 when booting up and scroll through bios options and see if you can add more ram to the graphics card. This will take away some system ram, but will make the video more smooth… If F10 doesn’t get you into bios look up your manual.”

Apparently with HP and ATI the vram and ram are shared, I have 6gb ram and theres no way games are using it all, could relocation work?[/quote]Thats how most onboard graphics cards work. Also, memory is rarely an issue for video cards, the clock frequency is.

Read full topic

item.title: External graphics card for laptops
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Turns out the external cards are over $600 and use a proprietary port

But I also found:

“What you can do is check in the bios, by hitting F10 when booting up and scroll through bios options and see if you can add more ram to the graphics card. This will take away some system ram, but will make the video more smooth… If F10 doesn’t get you into bios look up your manual.”

Apparently with HP and ATI the vram and ram are shared, I have 6gb ram and theres no way games are using it all, could relocation work?

Read full topic

item.title: External graphics card for laptops
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Only some laptops support it as far as i know, and it only works with ATI (which you already have).

http://www.amd.com/us/products/technologies/ati-xgp/Pages/ati-xgp.aspx

Read full topic
